Keywords: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
images.Headline: Patterns left in the sand by the retreating tide at Whiteford Sands on the Gower Peninsula, Wales.
images.Title: Maritime Motif
images.CaptionAbstract:
I loved the patterns left on the beach at Whiteford Sands on the Gower Peninsula. Although the patterns repeated over quite large areas, every so often the pattern would change to something distinctly different, as if the sea had got bored of doing the same thing over and over again and decided to move onto something new.

This particular pattern looks a bit like tyre tracks, but is completely naturally formed.

Keywords: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
images.Headline: A waterfall swollen by heavy rains on Levers Water Beck in the Lake District.
images.Title: In the Spray Zone
images.CaptionAbstract: I'm not sure if this waterfall, on Levers Water Beck in the Lake District, is anything special usually... but after days of rain brought by the remnants of Hurricane Gonzalo, which had blown in off the Atlantic the previous week, it's raw power was an invigorating sight to witness.

images.Headline: An ancient, lichen-encrusted piece of wood, once a majestic tree, forms a natural piece of art.
images.Title: Abstract #2
images.Sublocation: Shingle Hill on the Greensand Way
images.CaptionAbstract: An ancient, lichen-encrusted piece of wood, once a majestic tree, forms a natural piece of art.

Keywords: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
images.Headline: A double rainbow arches between Loch Brittle and Sgùrr nan Gobhar on the Isle of Skye.
images.Title: Rainbow Valley
images.CaptionAbstract:
I'm not afraid to admit it: until just now I didn't know the colours on the outer rainbow are reversed compared to the colours on the inner rainbow. But then what normal person could remain level-headed enough to notice something like that when presented with such a sight.

This double rainbow here arches between Loch Brittle and Sgùrr nan Gobhar on the Isle of Skye.

images.Headline: Moss on the bark of an old oak tree
images.Title: Mossy Oak

images.Headline: The sun fingers some bushes and a rocky outcrop in Mojave National Preserve.
images.Title: Granite Mountains
images.CaptionAbstract:
A couple of years ago I went to the US on what is possibly the most spontaneous business trip ever to have occurred (Thursday: "Where do you fancy going?", and we were on a plane to Los Angeles on Friday morning!).

One day saw us driving back to LA through the Mojave National Preserve. It was definitely a mixed blessing being in a new and amazing place while being somewhat limited in my ability to get out and explore it properly. Thankfully the desert is a kind place to the photographer and we happened to be there at the right time of day, so it didn't take long to find some half-decent compositions during a road-side stop by the Granite Mountains.

images.Headline: Red sorrel (rumex acetosella) in long grass is blown by strong wind near Devil's Dyke, Sussex.
images.Title: Sorrel in the Wind
images.CaptionAbstract: Trying to capture a sense of the power of the wind that day. Taken at the bottom of Devil's Dyke in Sussex.

Keywords: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
images.Headline: Leaves of a grey tree pincushion (Leucospermum conocarpodendron) in Kew Gardens, showing the fine silvery hairs which give the leaves their grey appearance.
images.Title: Cripplewood
images.CaptionAbstract:
A grey tree pincushion in the Temperate House at Kew Gardens. The common Afrikaans name Kreupelhout translates to “Cripplewood”, referring to the bent and twisted growth that the branches can exhibit.

Although abundant, grey tree pincushion is classed as vulnerable due to not only the usual threats of habitat loss, but also the reduction of the population of native ants, which the grey tree pincushion relies on for seed dispersal, at the hands of alient ant species. Ants are attracted to the elaiosomes (fleshy structures attached to the seeds) and the native ants carry the seeds back to their nests to eat the elaiosomes, where the seeds are protected underground from fires as well as from being eaten by other animals. After a fire, the seeds then germinate. Invasive ants, on the other hand, are less concerned about the sustainability of their food source and gorge on the elaiosomes without performing the necessary duties, leaving the seeds unprotected from fire.

But then the invasive ants would hardly be upholding the spirit of colonialism if they didn't ride roughshod over their new turf with complete indifference to the long-term ecological consequences of disrupting the delicate balance in which their evictees had lived in harmony for millennia.

Keywords: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
images.Headline: An orange-red sunset falls over Uig Bay on the Isle of Lewis and Harris
images.Title: Hebridean Rhythms
images.CaptionAbstract:
Surprisingly, though I remember the day clearly, I have no recollection of taking this particular photograph and was quite surprised by it when going through my library. There were a lot of interesting things going on with the light that evening, and given that this was such an easy shot to take - no need to carefully compose with the foreground for example - I guess it didn't really register that much and was pushed out of my mind by other images from that day which took more deliberation to make, and which I probably thought stronger at the time.

Still a good one though, I'd say.

Keywords: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
images.Headline: Sea thrift and lichen on coastal rocks on the Isle of Arran.
images.Title: Sea Thrift
images.CaptionAbstract: Sea thrift and lichen brighten up some coastal rocks near Newton Point on the Isle of Arran.

Keywords: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
images.Headline: A tranquil view of Uig Bay from Uig Beach on the Isle of Lewis.
images.Title: Longer Days to Come
images.CaptionAbstract:
A view from Uig Beach on an evening when the light just kept on giving and giving. So much so that I was still up shooting after it had turned 11pm, though that might also have had something to do with being nearly as close to Iceland as to London only 2 weeks before the summer solstice.

The slope of Uig Beach is extremely shallow, and so the rising tide devours the beach at a brisk rate. I clambered up and hover Machair Carnish to Tràigh Bhoisadair (Bhoisadair Beach) shortly after taking this shot, and by the time I came back an hour or two later there was no option but to get my socks wet.

Keywords: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
images.Headline: A fern with striking croziers by East Kyd Brook in Crofton Woods, with Crofton Heath beyond.
images.Title: Cradle of Life
images.CaptionAbstract:
Ferns are in abundance right now by East Kyd Brook. The new fronds of hart's-tongue are charming and maybe I will post a photo of those soon, but this Dryopteris Affinis has been on my radar since I explored along the brook a couple of weeks ago.

Confusingly, East Kyd Brook, as it is labelled on maps when it is labelled at all, is to the west of Kyd Brook. Perhaps there is or was another branch of the tributary of the River Quaggy somewhere further to the west, though if so then it is probably somewhat hidden and inaccessible now due to housing around.

Local historian Paul Browning's blog Running Past provides an amazingly forensic account of the River Quaggy and it's tributaries - a herculean task. OS maps don't help much and it was always a mystery to me where the Kyd Brook came from and where it went when periodically disappearing from the map.

Keywords: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
images.Headline: A flash of new-growth green in Shoreham wood, putting on one of the UK's best displays of bluebells.
images.Title: A Few Thousand of my Favourite Things
images.CaptionAbstract:
Bluebells, bluebells and bluebells... these are a few thousand of my favourite things. More, probably. I didn't count them all.

This is the best location that I know of to see one of the UK's best seasonal displays. Unfortunately I probably won't be able to get there this year now un-necessary travel is banned, but the bluebells in the woods near my house are coming along nicely. Nothing to match Shoreham woods, but nothing to be sniffed at either.

Keywords: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
images.Headline: A small spider in a tiny web, on a Black Lace Eler plant (Sambuca Nigris) backlit by the sun.
images.Title: Born to spin
images.CaptionAbstract: A tiny spider in a tiny web on a Black Lace elder plant. This brilliantly simple but effective design has been independently reinvented by every spider that ever lived. Because spiders don't need to be taught how to spin a web - they are just born with the instinct.

Keywords: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
images.Headline: Some grassy mounds emerge from very wet and boggy ground in Gleann Easan Biorach on the Isle of Arran.
images.Title: The Hard Path
images.CaptionAbstract: The going gets a little tough in Gleann Easan Biorach.

Keywords: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
images.Headline: A long exposure of an illuminated tree at night, with orange clouds and stars out.
images.Title: Alone in the Woods

images.Headline: An abstract photo. See in it what you will.
images.Title: Abstract #1

images.Headline: Snow-capped mountains near Tromsø, Northern Sweden a couple of weeks from the start of the Polar Night.
images.Title: Last Light
images.CaptionAbstract:
A permanent sort of ethereal twilight pervades during the last weeks before the Polar Night arrives. The sun only rises a couple of degrees above the true horizon, so is completely blocked by the mountains.

This view is looking down the valley of the Sørbotnelva, which flows towards the camera into the Ramfjord at Sørbotn, just hidden from sight.

images.Headline: The last surviving snow from last year's snowfall, with rocks and a mountain in the background.
images.Title: Survivor
images.CaptionAbstract: Taken on an overnight hiking trip to some cabins near Tromsø. It was mid-November and snow had not yet fallen, so this was the last remains from the previous year. With less than 2 weeks to go until permanent night time, the sun no longer rose high enough for this snow to have to endure it's direct rays, so it would live to see another (polar) day.

images.Headline: Sheep looking at the camera in a field adjacent to the Swale National Nature Reserve on the Isle of Sheppey.
images.Title: Sheep Island
images.CaptionAbstract:
These sheep are natural models, and didn't need any direction from me to form this pleasing positioning.

The Isle of Sheppey is an island in the Thames Estuary, and its name is derived from Old English Sceapig, meaning "Sheep Island". Besides sheep, it is also home to a creature you would be slightly more surprised to find in the UK — the European yellow-tailed scorpion, which hitched a ride from Italy on a ship in the 18th century and found the UK climate not too disagreeable, apparently. They can survive here thanks to an extremely slow metabolism, only bothering to move for the strict essentials of hunting for food (which sometimes includes each other) and mating.

Keywords: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
images.Headline: A thick-trunked oak tree in Crofton woods, leafless and covered in ivy and moss in winter.
images.Title: The Other Side
images.CaptionAbstract: I had spotted this oak tree some distance off the path during my walks in Crofton woods, and had been intending to return with my camera to capture what looked, at least from a distance, like a promising subject. When I finally did, and went off the path to approach the it, I was shocked to discover that it was right next to another path that I had walked along several times before, completely failing to notice this ancient oak as anything of particular interest from the other side, from which it's verdant cloak was not visible. It just goes to show what a change of direction can do, and also just how disorienting woods can be. Even when you think you know them, they still have the ability to surprise you.

Keywords: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
images.Headline: A wind-fallen branch, encrusted in lichen, lies in a flooded path, with trees reflected.
images.Title: After Brendan
images.CaptionAbstract:
Watching the heavy rain and strong winds as Storm Brendan raged outside, I knew that there would be some good photos to be had after it had all died down. I got to Crofton Woods maybe slightly later than I had hoped and it was already pretty dark, but I had brought my headtorch with me so it was the perfect time to try out a bit of light painting.

This branch is lying in what is usually a path, only it was flooded as far as I could see (at least by the light of my headtorch) and deeper than Kyd Brook is most of the time. I spent quite a while improving the technique of illuminating all of the different bits of it evenly without illuminating any of the water, and by the time I had finished it was almost pitch black.

Keywords: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
images.Headline: Two birch trees stand among densely packed, red-brown bracken in Autumn in a woodland, with the sun close to the horizon.
images.Title: Monoculture
images.CaptionAbstract: Where bracken grows, little else can. It ruthlessly outcompetes other plants, and some studies have also shown that when it dies back, the rain leaches toxins from it which inhibits other plant growth.

Keywords: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
Wye Valley Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty
images.Headline: A small-leaved lime tree with the last of its fruits in winter, with a misty woodland background.
images.Title: The Last of Autumn's Bounty
images.CaptionAbstract:
When I stopped for lunch under this small-leaved lime tree during a walk along part of Offa's Dyke Path, I didn't realise that it would also give me the strongest image of the day.

Small-leaved limes are indicators of ancient woodland in the UK, and this lime tree is not lying - the misty backdrop you see here is Cadora woods, one of the many areas of ancient woodland in the Wye Valley.

Keywords: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
images.Headline: A birch tree is illuminated by the full moon in a wood.
images.Title: Moonbolt
images.CaptionAbstract: The moon throws down a bolt of light, using this birch tree as its vehicle. I took a spontaneous moonlit stroll through the woods near my house on the recent full moon, and it reminded me of the last time I did so, when I took my camera and made this photo. I'm planning to plan ahead next time and take my camera out on the next full moon.

Keywords: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
images.Headline: A clump of ferns cluster around a large rock in a glacial valley, with a Cir Mhor in the background,
images.Title: Green Embrace
images.CaptionAbstract: A clump of ferns cluster around a boulder in Glen Sannox on the Isle of Arran. Arran is a mecca for students of geology, who swarm to the island in summer months, and are known affectionately (I presume) to the locals as "Jolly Boys". I guess it's hard not to be happy when surrounded by a magnificent glacial landscape such as this. I think the gender balance in the Earth Sciences is better than it used to be: perhaps the phrase has remained unchanged because it has a certain ring to it.

Keywords: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
images.Headline: Barnacles create a streak of white on black schist on the North coast of Arran.
images.Title: Barnacle Unconformity
images.CaptionAbstract: These barnacles are jostling for space so much here that at first glance it looks like there is a junction between two types of rock, which is actually what I thought was the case at first. If you do want to find 2 different types of rocks adjoining each other, then not far from here you will find Hutton's Unconformity, one of several places noted by geologist James Hutton where different types of rocks of different ages are found adjoining each other, with the younger rock on top. Hutton used such locations as evidence for his theory of how the Earth's crust is continually undergoing the same natural processes today which formed it as it is in the present day. This theory of Uniformitarianism, as it was called, challenged the then accepted idea that the Earth was only a few thousand years old. That was in the late 18th century, but it was only in the early 20th century that estimates of the age of the Earth reached the billions rather than millions of years, at least without being largely ignored.

images.Headline: 2 men waiting at a bus stop on a very steep road in Chinatown, San Francisco
images.Title: Lean-to

Keywords: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
images.Headline: 3 cows grazing, with the Cuillin peak of  Blà Bheinn in the background.
images.Title: Beneath Blà Bheinn
images.CaptionAbstract: Taken from near the shore of Loch Slapin, where the road makes a sharp U-turn to circumvent it on the way to Elgol. To me, the cows and sheep are as integral a part of the Skye landscape as the sweeping sea lochs and lofty peaks.

Keywords: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
images.Headline: A view of the Black Cuillins across Loch Scavaig
images.Title: Loch Scavaig
images.CaptionAbstract: A view across Loch Scavaig towards Gars-bheinn and the Black Cuillin surrounding Loch Coruisk, appropriately cast into shadows by the clouds.

Keywords: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
images.Headline: A streak of white sand on a mostly black volcanic sand beach in Glen Brittle, Isle of Skye.
images.Title: Neptune's Canvas
images.CaptionAbstract: A streak of white sand marbles the mostly black volcanic sand of Glen Brittle beach. Twice a day, the sea leaves patterns of light and dark on the beach before, etch-a-sketch style, erasing everything and starting again.

images.Headline: Cows by Loch Brittle on Rubha an Dùnain, the Isle of Skye.
images.Title: Cows by Loch Brittle
images.CaptionAbstract: Cows by Loch Brittle on Rubha an Dùnain, the Isle of Skye.

Keywords: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
images.Headline: Northern gannet colony at Boreray, St. Kilda
images.Title: Boreray
images.CaptionAbstract: Boreray, part of the St. Kilda archipelago, wastes no time getting to the point, being the smallest Scottish island with an elevation of over 1000ft. It is home to the world's 2nd largest colony of northern gannet, which were the staple food of the St. Kildans for most of the island's history, until a demand for fulmar products (oil and feathers) in the 18th century persuaded them to develop a taste for the smaller bird. Despite being even more inhospitable than Hirta, the main island of the archipelago, archaeological evidence suggests Boreray was inhabited at one point. In more recent times, Boreray was only temporarily inhabited for the purposes of catching gannets and puffins (the latter quarry being reserved for the women), and tending the semi-feral sheep. When in distress, communication was made with Hirta by inverting patches of turf, the position and size of which could signify either lack of provisions, illness, injury or death.

Keywords: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
images.Headline: Visitors at the Natural History Museum in London examine a display of insects in Hintze Hall.
images.Title: Insect exhibit at Hintze Hall
images.CaptionAbstract: Pretty busy at the Natural History Museum, even before you count the tourists.

Keywords: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
images.Headline: Tyre tracks leading towards a field of sheep  in Shoreham, Kent.
images.Title: Tyre Tracks at Dusk
images.CaptionAbstract:
If you're walking the Darent Valley Path from Sevenoaks to the Thames, Shoreham is one of the most delightful places you will pass through on the way, and well worth planning a bit of extra time for. Its woods in particular—; including Meenfield wood, which is the one you can see in this photo — are carpeted with blubells in the spring.

It's amazing that I took this photo over 2 years ago, but haven't had time to upload it here (or any other photos for that matter, until last weekend) since starting my job shortly before this photo was taken. Hopefully I will start getting back into the swing of things now. I guess I let this website slip down a bit in my priorities, but I have recently decided to bump it up to number 2 in my list (after surviving/paying the bills).

Anyway, I would highly recommend doing the Darent Valley Path if you live in the south-east London Area. Someone I met once told me that tears came to his eyes when he reached the sea after walking the length of the Thames. You will probably manage to keep dry eyes upon reaching the muddy banks of the Thames after following the journey of its little tributary, but it's still a worthwhile excursion if you only have a day to spare.

images.Headline: A roe deer leaps through the grass at Chobham common, white rump patch on display.
images.Title: Roe Deer Scarpering
images.CaptionAbstract: I got the distinct impression that my presence wasn't appreciated by this roe deer and its fellow herdmembers when I stumbled upon their drinking spot. This female gave me a display of its white rump patch as it bounded away through the grass.

Keywords: Church of St. John the Baptist
United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
images.Headline: A man in a leather jacket walking down a narrow street, with a medieval church in the background.
images.Title: Black Jack Street
images.CaptionAbstract: Looking down Black Jack Street in Cirencester, towards the Church of St. John the Baptist.

images.Headline: Spray artist Tony Vegas displays a finished painting in the Fremont Street Experience, Las Vegas.
images.Title: Tony Vegas
images.CaptionAbstract: Me editing my photos could hardly be called a spectator sport. This guy, on the other hand, has turned making art into an art form. Vying for attention with contortionists, musicians and other street performers, Tony Vegas produces his paintings in frenzies of movement, sound and colour which draw sizeable crowds. He is seen here showing off a finished creation at the Fremont Street Experience. See him making a painting in just under 7 minutes <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FNJtyFu1dEs">here</a>

images.Headline: Rain falls from dark clouds above a red-orange landscape of hoodooes and coniferous trees.
images.Title: Rain over Bryce Canyon

images.Headline: Dasylirion leiophyllum (green sotol) in the University of California Botanical Garden.
images.Title: Green Sotol
images.CaptionAbstract: Dasylirion leiophyllum (commonly known as green sotol or smooth-leaf sotol) in the University of California Botanical Garden. It is native to North American, and common in the Chihuahan desert. The word "sotol" appears in the common names of many other species in this genus of the asparagus family. The distilled spirit sotol, however, is made from Dasylirion wheeleri, or desert spoon.

images.Headline: A puddle meanders towards a cow by the Severn Estuary, with a lighthouse on a small island in the background.
images.Title: Cow Pooing at Black Rock
images.CaptionAbstract: I managed to snap this cow with it's poo in mid-air (I hope it's not a reflection on what she thinks of my photo). Henri Cartier-Bresson would be proud.

images.Headline: Dead trees at Main Terrace in Mammoth Hot Springs.
images.Title: Mammoth Hot Springs
images.CaptionAbstract: Mammoth Hot Springs is a complex of hot springs in Yellowstone National Park. Travertine, a form of limestone deposited by the hot springs, is abundant here, and in places is tinted red, brown, orange or green by algae. Behind and on the right is Mount Everts.

images.Headline: A Zanzibari man looking up from his newspaper in a Stone Town alley.
images.Title: Cosy Reading Spot
images.CaptionAbstract: A local of Stone Town, Zanzibar, looks up from his Swahili newspaper. This was the first time I plucked up the courage to take a photo of a stranger from close range.

images.Headline: A close-up of a Grant's zebra (Equus quagga boehmi) in Ngorongoro Conservation Area.
images.Title: Zebra, Ngorongoro Crater
images.CaptionAbstract: One of a large herd of Zebras and Wildebeest in Ngorongoro Crater, the world's largest inactive, unfilled volcanic caldera.

images.Headline: A padlocked garage door with peeling paint and No Parking sign.
images.Title: 24h Access Required
images.Sublocation: 23 Park Street, formerly Henry Tanner's Chapel
images.CaptionAbstract:
I was drawn to the peeling paint and rust on this garage door, and only later when looking at Google Maps did I see that I had missed the little blue plaque right next to it. It was erected by the Cirencester Civic Society and reads:

23 Park Street. Formerly Henry Tanner's chapel, opened in 1854 for strict Baptists seceding from the Baptist Chapel in Coxwell Street

Keywords: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
images.Headline: The Coca-Cola London Eye, then the EDF Energy London Eye, at night viewed from below.
images.Title: The London Eye
images.CaptionAbstract: The London Eye looking pretty at night before it turned a sickly shade of Coca-Cola.

images.Headline: A man rolling a huge tyre along a dust road in Arusha, Tanzania.
images.Title: Rapid Roadside Assistance

Keywords: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
images.Headline: A man walking his dog over a weir at Levers Water reservoir in the Lake District.
images.Title: Weir Walking
images.CaptionAbstract: Braving the elements, a group of walkers wait for an ebb in the flow of water over Levers Water weir to make a crossing.

Keywords: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
images.Headline: A hunched elderly man with walking stick walking across the Savoy Hotel entrance.
images.Title: World in a Hurry
images.CaptionAbstract: A London city worker on his commute along the Strand, with the festively decorated entrance to the Savoy Theatre in the background.

Keywords: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
images.Headline: Fallow deer on a hill top with two Scots Pine trees in Knole Park.
images.Title: Deer at Dusk
images.CaptionAbstract: A herd of fallow deer stretch out along a hill top after sunset in Knole Park, with two Scots Pine trees illuminated from the side by the orange glow lingering in the sky.

images.Headline: Black Rock, along the River Severn in Monmouthsire. A cow and Charston Rock Lighthouse lie in the background.
images.Title: Cow and Lighthouse
images.CaptionAbstract: A solitary cow munches grass on the waterlogged banks of the River Severn at Black Rock. In the background, Charston rock lighthouse sits primed for action.

images.Headline: A male lion lying down in grass in Ngorongoro Conservation Area, Tanzania.
images.Title: Ngorongoro Lion
images.CaptionAbstract: A male lion in Ngorongoro Conservation Area in Tanzania.

Keywords: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
images.Headline: A tree stump in Meenfield Wood
images.Title: Sunstruck Stump
images.CaptionAbstract: I didn't set out to photograph these two tree stumps, but the setting sun came out from behind the clouds to create such an enticing composition that I thought it would be rude not to.

images.Headline: People in a crowded Darajani market in Zanzibar City, some wearing bargashia (traditional hats similar to the kofia).
images.Title: Bazaar
images.CaptionAbstract: Darajani Market, the main market of Stone Town Zanzibar, is mainly a food market, but this section sells a variety of other goods. Several men are wearing bargashia hats (like the kofia, but embroidered and lacking in pin holes), which are popular in Tanzania and northern Uganda.

images.Headline: Sunrise at Villach Hauptbahnhof (train station) where a timber laden train waits to set off.
images.Title: Villach Sunrise
images.CaptionAbstract: Sunrise at Villach Hauptbahnhof, just before this timber-laden train set off. Being a nocturnal creature, I don't get to see many sunrises, so I was quite excited by this.

images.Headline: The dazzling lightshow at the Fremont Street Experience and a girl in a white hat. Also a man dressed as Superman.
images.Title: In Amazing Technicolor
images.CaptionAbstract: This light show in Fremont Street was Downton Vegas' fightback against the gradual migration of activity the Strip. In attempt to lure back visitors, after the CEO of Paramount pictures refused permission to build a Starship Enterprise I thought this girl, standing alone, would make the perfect foreground to the light show. As I walked towards her, I suddenly realised that her perfect position was not as fortuitous as I first though - I saw in my peripheral vision she was with a friend and he was taking pictures of her, and that I was walking right in-between them! Fortunately he didn't notice as he had his eye to the viewfinder, and she didn't notice as she was looking the other way, giving me a chance to avoid the embarrassment, taking a position behind and to this side of him, profiting from his good directing. Thanks random dude!

images.Headline: A mute swan swimming in a pond at Caldicot Castle, with a tree and reflection in the background.
images.Title: Swan in a Tree
images.CaptionAbstract: This mute swan positioned itself perfectly for me in a pond in the grounds behind Caldicot Castle.

images.Headline: Love locks on the Pont des Arts in Paris.
images.Title: 45 Metric Tons of Love
images.CaptionAbstract: Padlocks left on the Pont des Arts in Paris by lovers young and old. The keys were thrown into the Seine according to ancient tradition. Not really though - the "tradition" only lasted for 7 years. By 2015 they numbered around the million mark and were removed for the sake of the bridge's structural integrity. The bridge is now decorated with padlock-themed street art on light-weight and unpadlockable wooden boards.

images.Headline: A man roller skating over a zebra crossing in Paris, with a family walking behind going in the opposite direction.
images.Title: Paris Street Roller
images.CaptionAbstract: An inline skater rolls over a zebra crossing on the quai des Célestins in le quartier de l'Arsenal.

images.Headline: A cluster of water lilies with flowers in the Monet Pool at Denver Botanic Gardens.
images.Title: Monet Pool
images.CaptionAbstract: The Monet pool in Denver Botanic Gardens is home to 150 species of the water lily, the plant that made Claude Monet so famous. I had left my easel at home, so went for a more photorealistic interpretation here.

images.Headline: An abstract image of heather with purple flowers and a birch branch on Chobham common. The camera was rotated during the exposure
images.Title: Heather Eddy
images.CaptionAbstract: An abstraction of newly enflowered heather and a fallen birch branch on Chobham Common.

Keywords: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
images.Headline: Shadows of passers-by in front of the London Eye.
images.Title: Shadow Play

Keywords: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
images.Headline: A Mini Cooper lit by a street light at night in Orpington.
images.Title: Insomnia

Keywords: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
images.Headline: A long and straight tree-lined footpath ending at the horizon in the Bathurst Estate, Cirencester.
images.Title: X

Keywords: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
images.Headline: A man wearing Converse shoes walking past a shoe shop on Oxford Street at Christmas.
images.Title: Shoe Shop

Keywords: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
images.Headline: Startrails and shooting star in the Lake District, with a disused mine shaft tower in silhouette.
images.Title: Disused Mine Shaft and Star Trails
images.CaptionAbstract: After a day of extremely heavy rain while I was staying in the Coppermines Valley near Coniston, the sky cleared for the first and pretty much only time during my visit to the Lake District. I decided to head back to this disused mine shaft, The Old Engine Shaft, to try and capture some star trails. I was curious what exactly the tower was used for. Apparently it held a trough feeding a huge water wheel which powered the pump and winding gear used in the shaft. Well done if you spotted the shooting star. This occurred within the first few frames so I was lucky enough to see it with my own eyes. Later I would have been too busy alternating between trying to sleep and trying to keep warm to notice it. Neither with much luck.

images.Headline: A little egret (Egretta garzetta) taking off from a cable over the river Danube in evening light.
images.Title: An Egret's Egress

images.Headline: The interior of Sainte Chapelle, showing the stained glass windows and vaulted ceiling.
images.Title: Inside God's Jewelry Box
images.CaptionAbstract: If you ever find yourself in a flurry to see the sights in Paris, do you self a favour - give the massive queues for Notre Dame a miss and pay a visit to Sainte Chapelle instead. What Notre Dame's less visited neighbour may lack in brutish grandeur, it makes up for in this; an impossible ratio of spindly stone to dazzling glass that will make you question how the roof stays up.

Keywords: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
images.Headline: A sheep running in warm sunlight in a field in Shoreham, Kent
images.Title: Baaalmy Afternoon

images.Headline: The view up Hauptplatz in Villach, with St. Jakob's Church in the background.
images.Title: Villach Sleeping
images.CaptionAbstract: There's nothing quite like experiencing a place for the first time before everyone's woken up. I spent just two hours in Villach; long enough to catch the sunrise back at the station before catching a train to Belgrade.

images.Headline: Five Grant's zebras walking across a plain in Serengeti National Park, Tanzania.
images.Title: Zebras of the Serengeti
images.CaptionAbstract: Zebras roaming the plains in Serengeti National Park, Tanzania.

images.Headline: The roof of the LDS Conference Centre in Salt Lake City, showing reflecting pool and spire.
images.Title: LDS Conference Center
images.CaptionAbstract: A 92 foot tower atop the roof of this building (yes roof, don't be fooled by the trees) gives a clue as to its religious significance, serving as the premier meeting place of the Mormon Church and housing, for this purpose, the largest theatre style auditorium in the world. Just walk into the building and in true Mormon style, someone will be there to greet you, eager to give you a tour. Out of view to the right is what is surely Salt Lake City's finest roof-top garden, so it's well worth a visit.

images.Headline: Three pine trees lit by sunset at Chobham common in Surrey.
images.Title: Evening at Chobham Common

images.Headline: Chickens for sale at a market in Stone Town, Zanzibar.
images.Title: Chickens for Sale
images.CaptionAbstract: Chickens in market in Stone Town, Zanzibar.

images.Headline: A view of the Shard from London Waterloo East Railway Station at night.
images.Title: Next Stop: The Shard

images.Headline: An impala in Tarangire National Park, Tanzania
images.Title: Impala in the Grass
images.CaptionAbstract: An impala in Tarangire National Park - not the largest National Park in Tanzania, but home to an incredibly diverse mix of landscape and vegetation.

Keywords: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
images.Headline: A leafless canopy and blue sky in Shoreham Wood, Kent.
images.Title: Empty Canopy
images.CaptionAbstract: The canopy is bare in Shoreham woods, but not for much longer: spring is just around the corner. Shoreham woods puts on its best show in the spring, playing host to a legion of bluebells.

images.Headline: A leafless baobab tree (Adansonia digitata) in Tarangire National Park, Tanzania.
images.Title: Baobab Tree
